PublicIp.documentation: [EC2-Classic] The Elastic IP address. Required for EC2-Classic.

AssociationId.documentation: The ID of the current association between the original network ACL and the subnet.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

NetworkAclId.documentation: The ID of the new network ACL to associate with the subnet.

CidrBlock.documentation: The network range to allow or deny, in CIDR notation.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Egress.documentation:
Indicates whether to replace the egress rule.

Default: If no value is specified, we replace the ingress rule.

IcmpTypeCode.documentation: ICMP protocol: The ICMP type and code. Required if specifying 1 (ICMP) for the protocol.

PortRange.documentation: TCP or UDP protocols: The range of ports the rule applies to. Required if specifying 6 (TCP) or 17 (UDP) for the protocol.

Protocol.documentation: The IP protocol. You can specify all or -1 to mean all protocols.

RuleAction.documentation: Indicates whether to allow or deny the traffic that matches the rule.

RuleNumber.documentation: The rule number of the entry to replace.

DestinationCidrBlock.documentation: The CIDR address block used for the destination match. The value you provide must match the CIDR of an existing route in the table.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

GatewayId.documentation: The ID of an Internet gateway or virtual private gateway.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of a NAT instance in your VPC.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of a VPC peering connection.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

RouteTableId.documentation: The ID of the new route table to associate with the subnet.

Description.documentation: Descriptive text about the health state of your instance.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

EndTime.documentation: The time at which the reported instance health state ended.

ReasonCodes.documentation:
One or more reason codes that describes the health state of your instance.

  • instance-stuck-in-state: My instance is stuck in a state.

  • unresponsive: My instance is unresponsive.

  • not-accepting-credentials: My instance is not accepting my credentials.

  • password-not-available: A password is not available for my instance.

  • performance-network: My instance is experiencing performance problems which I believe are network related.

  • performance-instance-store: My instance is experiencing performance problems which I believe are related to the instance stores.

  • performance-ebs-volume: My instance is experiencing performance problems which I believe are related to an EBS volume.

  • performance-other: My instance is experiencing performance problems.

  • other: [explain using the description parameter]

StartTime.documentation: The time at which the reported instance health state began.

Status.documentation: The status of all instances listed.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

SpotFleetRequestConfig.documentation: The configuration for the Spot fleet request.

SpotFleetRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot fleet request.

AvailabilityZoneGroup.documentation:
The user-specified name for a logical grouping of bids.

When you specify an Availability Zone group in a Spot Instance request, all Spot instances in the request are launched in the same Availability Zone. Instance proximity is maintained with this parameter, but the choice of Availability Zone is not. The group applies only to bids for Spot Instances of the same instance type. Any additional Spot instance requests that are specified with the same Availability Zone group name are launched in that same Availability Zone, as long as at least one instance from the group is still active.

If there is no active instance running in the Availability Zone group that you specify for a new Spot instance request (all instances are terminated, the bid is expired, or the bid falls below current market), then Amazon EC2 launches the instance in any Availability Zone where the constraint can be met. Consequently, the subsequent set of Spot instances could be placed in a different zone from the original request, even if you specified the same Availability Zone group.

Default: Instances are launched in any available Availability Zone.

ClientToken.documentation: Unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. For more information, see How to Ensure Idempotency in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

InstanceCount.documentation:
The maximum number of Spot instances to launch.

Default: 1

LaunchGroup.documentation:
The instance launch group. Launch groups are Spot instances that launch together and terminate together.

Default: Instances are launched and terminated individually

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum hourly price (bid) for any Spot instance launched to fulfill the request.

ValidFrom.documentation:
The start date of the request. If this is a one-time request, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until all instances launch, the request expires, or the request is canceled. If the request is persistent, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until it expires or is canceled.

Default: The request is effective indefinitely.

ValidUntil.documentation:
The end date of the request. If this is a one-time request, the request remains active until all instances launch, the request is canceled, or this date is reached. If the request is persistent, it remains active until it is canceled or this date and time is reached.

Default: The request is effective indefinitely.

RequestSpotLaunchSpecification.documentation: Describes the launch specification for an instance.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block device mapping entries.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

Default: false

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instance.

UserData.documentation: The Base64-encoded MIME user data to make available to the instances.

OwnerId.documentation: The ID of the AWS account that owns the reservation.

RequesterId.documentation: The ID of the requester that launched the instances on your behalf (for example, AWS Management Console or Auto Scaling).

ReservedInstanceLimitPrice.documentation: Describes the limit price of a Reserved Instance offering.

Amount.documentation: Used for Reserved Instance Marketplace offerings. Specifies the limit price on the total order (instanceCount * price).

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency in which the limitPrice amount is specified. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which the Reserved Instance can be used.

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency of the Reserved Instance. It's specified using ISO 4217 standard currency codes. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

Duration.documentation: The duration of the Reserved Instance, in seconds.

End.documentation: The time when the Reserved Instance expires.

FixedPrice.documentation: The purchase price of the Reserved Instance.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type on which the Reserved Instance can be used.

RecurringCharges.documentation: The recurring charge tag assigned to the resource.

Start.documentation: The date and time the Reserved Instance started.

State.documentation: The state of the Reserved Instance purchase.

UsagePrice.documentation: The usage price of the Reserved Instance, per hour.

ReservedInstancesConfiguration.documentation: Describes the configuration settings for the modified Reserved Instances.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone for the modified Reserved Instances.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type for the modified Reserved Instances.

Platform.documentation: The network platform of the modified Reserved Instances, which is either EC2-Classic or EC2-VPC.

ReservedInstancesId.documentation: Describes the ID of a Reserved Instance.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive key supplied by the client to ensure that the request is idempotent. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

InstanceCounts.documentation: The number of instances in this state.

PriceSchedules.documentation: The price of the Reserved Instance listing.

ReservedInstancesListingId.documentation: The ID of the Reserved Instance listing.

Status.documentation: The status of the Reserved Instance listing.

StatusMessage.documentation: The reason for the current status of the Reserved Instance listing. The response can be blank.

UpdateDate.documentation: The last modified timestamp of the listing.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive key supplied by the client to ensure that the request is idempotent. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

CreateDate.documentation: The time when the modification request was created.

EffectiveDate.documentation: The time for the modification to become effective.

ModificationResults.documentation: Contains target configurations along with their corresponding new Reserved Instance IDs.

ReservedInstancesIds.documentation: The IDs of one or more Reserved Instances.

ReservedInstancesModificationId.documentation: A unique ID for the Reserved Instance modification.

Status.documentation: The status of the Reserved Instances modification request.

UpdateDate.documentation: The time when the modification request was last updated.

ReservedInstancesId.documentation: The ID for the Reserved Instances that were created as part of the modification request. This field is only available when the modification is fulfilled.

TargetConfiguration.documentation: The target Reserved Instances configurations supplied as part of the modification request.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which the Reserved Instance can be used.

CurrencyCode.documentation: The currency of the Reserved Instance offering you are purchasing. It's specified using ISO 4217 standard currency codes. At this time, the only supported currency is USD.

Duration.documentation: The duration of the Reserved Instance, in seconds.

FixedPrice.documentation: The purchase price of the Reserved Instance.

InstanceType.documentation: The instance type on which the Reserved Instance can be used.

Marketplace.documentation: Indicates whether the offering is available through the Reserved Instance Marketplace (resale) or AWS. If it's a Reserved Instance Marketplace offering, this is true.

PricingDetails.documentation: The pricing details of the Reserved Instance offering.

RecurringCharges.documentation: The recurring charge tag assigned to the resource.

ReservedInstancesOfferingId.documentation: The ID of the Reserved Instance offering.

UsagePrice.documentation: The usage price of the Reserved Instance, per hour.

Attribute.documentation: The attribute to reset (currently you can only reset the launch permission attribute).

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

SourceDestCheck.documentation: The source/destination checking attribute. Resets the value to true.

Attribute.documentation: The attribute to reset. Currently, only the attribute for permission to create volumes can be reset.

Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Status.documentation: The move status for the IP address.

CidrIp.documentation: The CIDR IP address range. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

FromPort.documentation: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number. For the ICMP type number, use -1 to specify all ICMP types.

IpPermissions.documentation: A set of IP permissions. You can't specify a destination security group and a CIDR IP address range.

IpProtocol.documentation: The IP protocol name (tcp, udp, icmp) or number (see Protocol Numbers). Use -1 to specify all.

SourceSecurityGroupName.documentation: The name of a destination security group. To revoke outbound access to a destination security group, we recommend that you use a set of IP permissions instead.

SourceSecurityGroupOwnerId.documentation: The AWS account number for a destination security group. To revoke outbound access to a destination security group, we recommend that you use a set of IP permissions instead.

ToPort.documentation: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP code number. For the ICMP code number, use -1 to specify all ICMP codes for the ICMP type.

CidrIp.documentation: The CIDR IP address range. You can't specify this parameter when specifying a source security group.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

FromPort.documentation: The start of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP type number. For the ICMP type number, use -1 to specify all ICMP types.

GroupId.documentation: The ID of the security group. Required for a security group in a nondefault VPC.

GroupName.documentation: [EC2-Classic, default VPC] The name of the security group.

IpPermissions.documentation: A set of IP permissions. You can't specify a source security group and a CIDR IP address range.

IpProtocol.documentation: The IP protocol name (tcp, udp, icmp) or number (see Protocol Numbers). Use -1 to specify all.

SourceSecurityGroupName.documentation: [EC2-Classic, default VPC] The name of the source security group. You can't specify this parameter in combination with the following parameters: the CIDR IP address range, the start of the port range, the IP protocol, and the end of the port range. For EC2-VPC, the source security group must be in the same VPC.

SourceSecurityGroupOwnerId.documentation: [EC2-Classic, default VPC] The AWS account ID of the source security group. For EC2-VPC, the source security group must be in the same VPC. You can't specify this parameter in combination with the following parameters: the CIDR IP address range, the IP protocol, the start of the port range, and the end of the port range. To revoke a specific rule for an IP protocol and port range, use a set of IP permissions instead.

ToPort.documentation: The end of port range for the TCP and UDP protocols, or an ICMP code number. For the ICMP code number, use -1 to specify all ICMP codes for the ICMP type.

Route.documentation: Describes a route in a route table.

DestinationCidrBlock.documentation: The CIDR block used for the destination match.

GatewayId.documentation: The ID of a gateway attached to your VPC.

InstanceId.documentation: The ID of a NAT instance in your VPC.

InstanceOwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the owner of the instance.

Origin.documentation:
Describes how the route was created.

  • CreateRouteTable indicates that route was automatically created when the route table was created.
  • CreateRoute indicates that the route was manually added to the route table.
  • EnableVgwRoutePropagation indicates that the route was propagated by route propagation.

State.documentation: The state of the route. The blackhole state indicates that the route's target isn't available (for example, the specified gateway isn't attached to the VPC, or the specified NAT instance has been terminated).

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of the VPC peering connection.

Associations.documentation: The associations between the route table and one or more subnets.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the route table.

RouteTableAssociation.documentation: Describes an association between a route table and a subnet.

Main.documentation: Indicates whether this is the main route table.

RouteTableAssociationId.documentation: The ID of the association between a route table and a subnet.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet. A subnet ID is not returned for an implicit association.

Enabled.documentation: Indicates whether monitoring is enabled for the instance.

ClientToken.documentation:
Unique, case-sensitive identifier you provide to ensure the idempotency of the request. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

Constraints: Maximum 64 ASCII characters

DisableApiTermination.documentation:
If you set this parameter to true, you can't terminate the instance using the Amazon EC2 console, CLI, or API; otherwise, you can. If you set this parameter to true and then later want to be able to terminate the instance, you must first change the value of the disableApiTermination attribute to false using ModifyInstanceAttribute. Alternatively, if you set InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior to terminate, you can terminate the instance by running the shutdown command from the instance.

Default: false

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instance is optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS-optimized instance.

Default: false

ImageId.documentation: The ID of the AMI, which you can get by calling DescribeImages.

InstanceInitiatedShutdownBehavior.documentation:
Indicates whether an instance stops or terminates when you initiate shutdown from the instance (using the operating system command for system shutdown).

Default: stop

InstanceType.documentation:
The instance type. For more information, see Instance Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Default: m1.small

KernelId.documentation:
The ID of the kernel.

We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

KeyName.documentation:
The name of the key pair. You can create a key pair using CreateKeyPair or ImportKeyPair.

If you do not specify a key pair, you can't connect to the instance unless you choose an AMI that is configured to allow users another way to log in.

MaxCount.documentation:
The maximum number of instances to launch. If you specify more instances than Amazon EC2 can launch in the target Availability Zone, Amazon EC2 launches the largest possible number of instances above MinCount.

Constraints: Between 1 and the maximum number you're allowed for the specified instance type. For more information about the default limits, and how to request an increase, see How many instances can I run in Amazon EC2 in the Amazon EC2 General FAQ.

MinCount.documentation:
The minimum number of instances to launch. If you specify a minimum that is more instances than Amazon EC2 can launch in the target Availability Zone, Amazon EC2 launches no instances.

Constraints: Between 1 and the maximum number you're allowed for the specified instance type. For more information about the default limits, and how to request an increase, see How many instances can I run in Amazon EC2 in the Amazon EC2 General FAQ.

PrivateIpAddress.documentation:
[EC2-VPC] The primary IP address. You must specify a value from the IP address range of the subnet.

Only one private IP address can be designated as primary. Therefore, you can't specify this parameter if PrivateIpAddresses.n.Primary is set to true and PrivateIpAddresses.n.PrivateIpAddress is set to an IP address.

Default: We select an IP address from the IP address range of the subnet.

RamdiskId.documentation:
The ID of the RAM disk.

We recommend that you use PV-GRUB instead of kernels and RAM disks. For more information, see PV-GRUB in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

SecurityGroupIds.documentation:
One or more security group IDs. You can create a security group using CreateSecurityGroup.

Default: Amazon EC2 uses the default security group.

SecurityGroups.documentation:
[EC2-Classic, default VPC] One or more security group names. For a nondefault VPC, you must use security group IDs instead.

Default: Amazon EC2 uses the default security group.

SubnetId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The ID of the subnet to launch the instance into.

UserData.documentation: The Base64-encoded MIME user data for the instances.

S3Storage.documentation: Describes the storage parameters for S3 and S3 buckets for an instance store-backed AMI.

AWSAccessKeyId.documentation: The access key ID of the owner of the bucket. Before you specify a value for your access key ID, review and follow the guidance in Best Practices for Managing AWS Access Keys.

Bucket.documentation: The bucket in which to store the AMI. You can specify a bucket that you already own or a new bucket that Amazon EC2 creates on your behalf. If you specify a bucket that belongs to someone else, Amazon EC2 returns an error.

Prefix.documentation: The beginning of the file name of the AMI.

UploadPolicy.documentation: A Base64-encoded Amazon S3 upload policy that gives Amazon EC2 permission to upload items into Amazon S3 on your behalf.

UploadPolicySignature.documentation: The signature of the Base64 encoded JSON document.

IpPermissions.documentation: One or more inbound rules associated with the security group.

IpPermissionsEgress.documentation: [EC2-VPC] One or more outbound rules associated with the security group.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the owner of the security group.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the security group.

VpcId.documentation: [EC2-VPC] The ID of the VPC for the security group.

DataEncryptionKeyId.documentation: The data encryption key identifier for the snapshot. This value is a unique identifier that corresponds to the data encryption key that was used to encrypt the original volume or snapshot copy. Because data encryption keys are inherited by volumes created from snapshots, and vice versa, if snapshots share the same data encryption key identifier, then they belong to the same volume/snapshot lineage. This parameter is only returned by the DescribeSnapshots API operation.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The full ARN of the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) that was used to protect the volume encryption key for the parent volume.

OwnerAlias.documentation: The AWS account alias (for example, amazon, self) or AWS account ID that owns the snapshot.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the EBS snapshot owner.

Progress.documentation: The progress of the snapshot, as a percentage.

SnapshotId.documentation: The ID of the snapshot. Each snapshot receives a unique identifier when it is created.

StartTime.documentation: The time stamp when the snapshot was initiated.

StateMessage.documentation: Encrypted Amazon EBS snapshots are copied asynchronously. If a snapshot copy operation fails (for example, if the proper AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) permissions are not obtained) this field displays error state details to help you diagnose why the error occurred. This parameter is only returned by the DescribeSnapshots API operation.

VolumeId.documentation: The ID of the volume that was used to create the snapshot.

VolumeSize.documentation: The size of the volume, in GiB.

SnapshotDetail.documentation: Describes the snapshot created from the imported disk.

DeviceName.documentation: The block device mapping for the snapshot.

DiskImageSize.documentation: The size of the disk in the snapshot, in GiB.

Format.documentation: The format of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

Progress.documentation: The percentage of progress for the task.

SnapshotId.documentation: The snapshot ID of the disk being imported.

Status.documentation: A brief status of the snapshot creation.

StatusMessage.documentation: A detailed status message for the snapshot creation.

Url.documentation: The URL used to access the disk image.

SnapshotDiskContainer.documentation: The disk container object for the import snapshot request.

Description.documentation: The description of the disk image being imported.

Format.documentation:
The format of the disk image being imported.

Valid values: RAW | VHD | VMDK | OVA

Url.documentation: The URL to the Amazon S3-based disk image being imported. It can either be a https URL (https://..) or an Amazon S3 URL (s3://..).

DiskImageSize.documentation: The size of the disk in the snapshot, in GiB.

Format.documentation: The format of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

Progress.documentation: The percentage of completion for the import snapshot task.

SnapshotId.documentation: The snapshot ID of the disk being imported.

Status.documentation: A brief status for the import snapshot task.

StatusMessage.documentation: A detailed status message for the import snapshot task.

Url.documentation: The URL of the disk image from which the snapshot is created.

UserBucket.documentation: The S3 bucket for the disk image.

SpotDatafeedSubscription.documentation: Describes the data feed for a Spot instance.

Bucket.documentation: The Amazon S3 bucket where the Spot instance data feed is located.

Fault.documentation: The fault codes for the Spot instance request, if any.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the account.

Prefix.documentation: The prefix that is prepended to data feed files.

State.documentation: The state of the Spot instance data feed subscription.

SpotFleetLaunchSpecification.documentation: Describes the launch specification for one or more Spot instances.

BlockDeviceMappings.documentation: One or more block device mapping entries.

EbsOptimized.documentation:
Indicates whether the instances are optimized for EBS I/O. This optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal EBS I/O performance. This optimization isn't available with all instance types. Additional usage charges apply when using an EBS Optimized instance.

Default: false

Monitoring.documentation: Enable or disable monitoring for the instances.

SecurityGroups.documentation: One or more security groups. To request an instance in a nondefault VPC, you must specify the ID of the security group. To request an instance in EC2-Classic or a default VPC, you can specify the name or the ID of the security group.

SpotPrice.documentation: The bid price per unit hour for the specified instance type. If this value is not specified, the default is the Spot bid price specified for the fleet. To determine the bid price per unit hour, divide the Spot bid price by the value of WeightedCapacity.

SubnetId.documentation: The ID of the subnet in which to launch the instances.

UserData.documentation: The Base64-encoded MIME user data to make available to the instances.

WeightedCapacity.documentation:
The number of units provided by the specified instance type. These are the same units that you chose to set the target capacity in terms (instances or a performance characteristic such as vCPUs, memory, or I/O).

If the target capacity divided by this value is not a whole number, we round the number of instances to the next whole number. If this value is not specified, the default is 1.

SpotFleetRequestConfig.documentation: Information about the configuration of the Spot fleet request.

SpotFleetRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot fleet request.

SpotFleetRequestState.documentation: The state of the Spot fleet request.

SpotFleetRequestConfigData.documentation: Describes the configuration of a Spot fleet request.

AllocationStrategy.documentation: Determines how to allocate the target capacity across the Spot pools specified by the Spot fleet request. The default is lowestPrice.

ClientToken.documentation: A unique, case-sensitive identifier you provide to ensure idempotency of your listings. This helps avoid duplicate listings. For more information, see Ensuring Idempotency.

IamFleetRole.documentation: Grants the Spot fleet permission to terminate Spot instances on your behalf when you cancel its Spot fleet request using CancelSpotFleetRequests or when the Spot fleet request expires, if you set terminateInstancesWithExpiration.

LaunchSpecifications.documentation: Information about the launch specifications for the Spot fleet request.

TargetCapacity.documentation: The number of units to request. You can choose to set the target capacity in terms of instances or a performance characteristic that is important to your application workload, such as vCPUs, memory, or I/O.

TerminateInstancesWithExpiration.documentation: Indicates whether running Spot instances should be terminated when the Spot fleet request expires.

ValidFrom.documentation: The start date and time of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). The default is to start fulfilling the request immediately.

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date and time of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). At this point, no new Spot instance requests are placed or enabled to fulfill the request.

AvailabilityZoneGroup.documentation: The Availability Zone group. If you specify the same Availability Zone group for all Spot instance requests, all Spot instances are launched in the same Availability Zone.

CreateTime.documentation: The date and time when the Spot instance request was created, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).

Fault.documentation: The fault codes for the Spot instance request, if any.

InstanceId.documentation: The instance ID, if an instance has been launched to fulfill the Spot instance request.

LaunchGroup.documentation: The instance launch group. Launch groups are Spot instances that launch together and terminate together.

LaunchedAvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone in which the bid is launched.

ProductDescription.documentation: The product description associated with the Spot instance.

SpotInstanceRequestId.documentation: The ID of the Spot instance request.

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum hourly price (bid) for any Spot instance launched to fulfill the request.

State.documentation: The state of the Spot instance request. Spot bid status information can help you track your Spot instance requests. For more information, see Spot Bid Status in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Status.documentation: The status code and status message describing the Spot instance request.

ValidFrom.documentation: The start date of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). If this is a one-time request, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until all instances launch, the request expires, or the request is canceled. If the request is persistent, the request becomes active at this date and time and remains active until it expires or is canceled.

ValidUntil.documentation: The end date of the request, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ). If this is a one-time request, the request remains active until all instances launch, the request is canceled, or this date is reached. If the request is persistent, it remains active until it is canceled or this date is reached.

Code.documentation: The reason code for the Spot instance state change.

Message.documentation: The message for the Spot instance state change.

SpotInstanceStatus.documentation: Describes the status of a Spot instance request.

UpdateTime.documentation: The date and time of the most recent status update, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the placement group (for cluster instances).

SpotPrice.documentation: Describes the maximum hourly price (bid) for any Spot instance launched to fulfill the request.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone.

SpotPrice.documentation: The maximum price (bid) that you are willing to pay for a Spot instance.

Timestamp.documentation: The date and time the request was created, in UTC format (for example, YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SSZ).

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

StartingInstances.documentation: Information about one or more started instances.

Code.documentation: The reason code for the state change.

Message.documentation:
The message for the state change.

  • Server.SpotInstanceTermination: A Spot Instance was terminated due to an increase in the market price.

  • Server.InternalError: An internal error occurred during instance launch, resulting in termination.

  • Server.InsufficientInstanceCapacity: There was insufficient instance capacity to satisfy the launch request.

  • Client.InternalError: A client error caused the instance to terminate on launch.

  • Client.InstanceInitiatedShutdown: The instance was shut down using the shutdown -h command from the instance.

  • Client.UserInitiatedShutdown: The instance was shut down using the Amazon EC2 API.

  • Client.VolumeLimitExceeded: The volume limit was exceeded.

  • Client.InvalidSnapshot.NotFound: The specified snapshot was not found.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

Force.documentation:
Forces the instances to stop. The instances do not have an opportunity to flush file system caches or file system metadata. If you use this option, you must perform file system check and repair procedures. This option is not recommended for Windows instances.

Default: false

StoppingInstances.documentation: Information about one or more stopped instances.

Storage.documentation: Describes the storage location for an instance store-backed AMI.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the subnet.

AvailableIpAddressCount.documentation: The number of unused IP addresses in the subnet. Note that the IP addresses for any stopped instances are considered unavailable.

CidrBlock.documentation: The CIDR block assigned to the subnet.

DefaultForAz.documentation: Indicates whether this is the default subnet for the Availability Zone.

MapPublicIpOnLaunch.documentation: Indicates whether instances launched in this subnet receive a public IP address.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC the subnet is in.

Key.documentation:
The key of the tag.

Constraints: Tag keys are case-sensitive and accept a maximum of 127 Unicode characters. May not begin with aws:

Value.documentation:
The value of the tag.

Constraints: Tag values are case-sensitive and accept a maximum of 255 Unicode characters.

ResourceId.documentation: The ID of the resource. For example, ami-1a2b3c4d.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

TerminatingInstances.documentation: Information about one or more terminated instances.

PrivateIpAddresses.documentation: The secondary private IP addresses to unassign from the network interface. You can specify this option multiple times to unassign more than one IP address.

DryRun.documentation: Checks whether you have the required permissions for the action, without actually making the request, and provides an error response. If you have the required permissions, the error response is DryRunOperation. Otherwise, it is UnauthorizedOperation.

InstanceMonitorings.documentation: Monitoring information for one or more instances.

UnsuccessfulItem.documentation: Information about items that were not successfully processed in a batch call.

UnsuccessfulItemError.documentation: Information about the error that occurred. For more information about errors, see Error Codes.

Message.documentation: The error message accompanying the error code.

UserBucket.documentation: Describes the S3 bucket for the disk image.

S3Bucket.documentation: The name of the S3 bucket where the disk image is located.

UserBucketDetails.documentation: Describes the S3 bucket for the disk image.

S3Bucket.documentation: The S3 bucket from which the disk image was created.

S3Key.documentation: The key from which the disk image was created.

UserData.documentation: Describes the user data to be made available to an instance.

Data.documentation: The Base64-encoded MIME user data for the instance.

UserIdGroupPair.documentation: Describes a security group and AWS account ID pair.

GroupName.documentation: The name of the security group. In a request, use this parameter for a security group in EC2-Classic or a default VPC only. For a security group in a nondefault VPC, use GroupId.

UserId.documentation: The ID of an AWS account. EC2-Classic only.

LastStatusChange.documentation: The date and time of the last change in status.

OutsideIpAddress.documentation: The Internet-routable IP address of the virtual private gateway's outside interface.

Status.documentation: The status of the VPN tunnel.

StatusMessage.documentation: If an error occurs, a description of the error.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone for the volume.

CreateTime.documentation: The time stamp when volume creation was initiated.

Encrypted.documentation: Indicates whether the volume will be encrypted.

Iops.documentation:
The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) that the volume supports. For Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes, this represents the number of IOPS that are provisioned for the volume. For General Purpose (SSD) volumes, this represents the baseline performance of the volume and the rate at which the volume accumulates I/O credits for bursting. For more information on General Purpose (SSD) baseline performance, I/O credits, and bursting, see Amazon EBS Volume Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Constraint: Range is 100 to 20000 for Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes and 3 to 10000 for General Purpose (SSD) volumes.

Condition: This parameter is required for requests to create io1 volumes; it is not used in requests to create standard or gp2 volumes.

KmsKeyId.documentation: The full ARN of the AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) that was used to protect the volume encryption key for the volume.

Size.documentation: The size of the volume, in GiBs.

SnapshotId.documentation: The snapshot from which the volume was created, if applicable.

VolumeType.documentation: The volume type. This can be gp2 for General Purpose (SSD) volumes, io1 for Provisioned IOPS (SSD) volumes, or standard for Magnetic volumes.

AttachTime.documentation: The time stamp when the attachment initiated.

DeleteOnTermination.documentation: Indicates whether the EBS volume is deleted on instance termination.

Size.documentation: The size of the volume, in GiB.

Code.documentation: The code identifying the operation, for example, enable-volume-io.

EventId.documentation: The ID of the event associated with this operation.

EventType.documentation: The event type associated with this operation.

Status.documentation: The intended status of the volume status.

NotAfter.documentation: The latest end time of the event.

NotBefore.documentation: The earliest start time of the event.

Status.documentation: The status of the volume.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone of the volume.

Events.documentation: A list of events associated with the volume.

DhcpOptionsId.documentation: The ID of the set of DHCP options you've associated with the VPC (or default if the default options are associated with the VPC).

InstanceTenancy.documentation: The allowed tenancy of instances launched into the VPC.

IsDefault.documentation: Indicates whether the VPC is the default VPC.

VpcAttachment.documentation: Describes an attachment between a virtual private gateway and a VPC.

VpcClassicLink.documentation: Describes whether a VPC is enabled for ClassicLink.

ClassicLinkEnabled.documentation: Indicates whether the VPC is enabled for ClassicLink.

CreationTimestamp.documentation: The date and time the VPC endpoint was created.

PolicyDocument.documentation: The policy document associated with the endpoint.

RouteTableIds.documentation: One or more route tables associated with the endpoint.

ServiceName.documentation: The name of the AWS service to which the endpoint is associated.

VpcId.documentation: The ID of the VPC to which the endpoint is associated.

ExpirationTime.documentation: The time that an unaccepted VPC peering connection will expire.

Status.documentation: The status of the VPC peering connection.

VpcPeeringConnectionId.documentation: The ID of the VPC peering connection.

VpcPeeringConnectionStateReason.documentation: Describes the status of a VPC peering connection.

Code.documentation: The status of the VPC peering connection.

Message.documentation: A message that provides more information about the status, if applicable.

VpcPeeringConnectionVpcInfo.documentation: Describes a VPC in a VPC peering connection.

OwnerId.documentation: The AWS account ID of the VPC owner.

CustomerGatewayConfiguration.documentation: The configuration information for the VPN connection's customer gateway (in the native XML format). This element is always present in the CreateVpnConnection response; however, it's present in the DescribeVpnConnections response only if the VPN connection is in the pending or available state.

CustomerGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the customer gateway at your end of the VPN connection.

Routes.documentation: The static routes associated with the VPN connection.

State.documentation: The current state of the VPN connection.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the VPN connection.

VpnGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private gateway at the AWS side of the VPN connection.

StaticRoutesOnly.documentation: Indicates whether the VPN connection uses static routes only. Static routes must be used for devices that don't support BGP.
Indicates whether the VPN connection uses static routes only. Static routes must be used for devices that don't support BGP.

AvailabilityZone.documentation: The Availability Zone where the virtual private gateway was created.

State.documentation: The current state of the virtual private gateway.

Tags.documentation: Any tags assigned to the virtual private gateway.

Type.documentation: The type of VPN connection the virtual private gateway supports.

VpcAttachments.documentation: Any VPCs attached to the virtual private gateway.

VpnGatewayId.documentation: The ID of the virtual private gateway.

VpnStaticRoute.documentation: Describes a static route for a VPN connection.

DestinationCidrBlock.documentation: The CIDR block associated with the local subnet of the customer data center.

State.documentation: The current state of the static route.
